com.thomsonreuters.upa.codec

Class DataTypes

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.thomsonreuters.upa.codec.DataTypes

  • public class DataTypes
extends java.lang.Object
    Defines enumerations for UPA primitive and container types.

    • Field Detail

      • UNKNOWN

        public static final int UNKNOWN
        Indicates that type is unknown. Only valid when decoding a Field List type where a dictionary look-up is required to determine the type). This type cannot be passed into encoding or decoding methods.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • INT

        public static final int INT
        A signed integer type. Can currently represent a value of up to 63 bits along with a one bit sign (positive or negative).
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • UINT

        public static final int UINT
        An unsigned integer type. Can currently represent an unsigned value with precision of up to 64 bits.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • FLOAT

        public static final int FLOAT
        A four-byte floating point type. Can represent the same range of values allowed with the system float type. Follows IEEE 754 specification.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • DOUBLE

        public static final int DOUBLE
        An eight-byte floating point type. Can represent the same range of values allowed with the system double type. Follows IEEE 754 specification.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • REAL

        public static final int REAL
        An optimized RWF representation of a decimal or fractional value which typically requires less bytes on the wire than float or double types. The user specifies a value with a hint for converting to decimal or fractional representation.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • DATE

        public static final int DATE
        Defines a date with month, day, and year values.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • TIME

        public static final int TIME
        Defines a time with hour, minute, second, and millisecond values. For more details on this type.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • DATETIME

        public static final int DATETIME
        Combined representation of date and time. Contains all members of DATE and TIME.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • QOS

        public static final int QOS
        Defines QoS information such as data timeliness (e.g. real time) and rate (e.g. tick-by-tick). Allows a user to send QoS information as part of the data payload. Similar information can also be conveyed using multiple UPA message headers.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • STATE

        public static final int STATE
        Represents data and stream state information. Allows a user to send state information as part of data payload. Similar information can also be conveyed in several UPA message headers.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • ENUM

        public static final int ENUM
        Represents an enumeration type, defined as an unsigned two-byte value. Many times, this enumeration value is cross-referenced with an enumeration dictionary (e.g., enumtype.def) or a well-known enumeration definition.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • ARRAY

        public static final int ARRAY
        The UPA Array type allows users to represent a simple base primitive type list (all primitive types except Array). The user can specify the base primitive type that an array carries and whether each is of a variable or fixed-length. Because the array is a primitive type, if any primitive value in the array updates, the entire array must be resent.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • BUFFER

        public static final int BUFFER
        Represents a raw byte buffer type. Any semantics associated with the data in this buffer is provided from outside of UPA, either via a field dictionary (e.g., RDMFieldDictionary), or a DMM definition
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • ASCII_STRING

        public static final int ASCII_STRING
        Represents an ASCII string which should contain only characters that are valid in ASCII specification. Because this might be NULL terminated, use the provided length when accessing content. UPA does not enforce or validate any encoding standard, and this is the responsibility of the encoding or decoding user.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • UTF8_STRING

        public static final int UTF8_STRING
        Represents a UTF8 string which should follow the UTF8 encoding standard and contain only characters valid within that set. Because this might be NULL terminated, use the provided length when accessing content. UPA does not enforce or validate any encoding standard, and this is the responsibility of the encoding or decoding user.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • RMTES_STRING

        public static final int RMTES_STRING
        Represents an RMTES (Reuters Multilingual Text Encoding Standard) string which should follow the RMTES encoding standard and contain only characters valid within that set. UPA does not enforce or validate encoding standards, so this is the responsibility of the encoding or decoding user.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • BASE_PRIMITIVE_MAX

        public static final int BASE_PRIMITIVE_MAX
        Maximum allowed value for base primitive types
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

        public static final int SET_PRIMITIVE_MIN
        Minimum allowed value for set defined primitive types
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • INT_1

        public static final int INT_1
        A signed, one-byte integer type. Can currently represent a value of up to 7 bits along with a one-bit sign (positive or negative). This set-defined primitive type cannot be represented as blank.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • UINT_1

        public static final int UINT_1
        An unsigned, one-byte integer type. Can currently represent an unsigned value with precision of up to 8 bits. This set-defined primitive type cannot be represented as blank.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • INT_2

        public static final int INT_2
        A signed, two-byte integer type. Can currently represent a value of up to 15 bits along with a one-bit sign (positive or negative). This set-defined primitive type cannot be represented as blank.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • UINT_2

        public static final int UINT_2
        An unsigned, two-byte integer type. Can currently represent an unsigned value with precision of up to 16 bits. This set-defined primitive type cannot be represented as blank.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • INT_4

        public static final int INT_4
        A signed, four-byte integer type. Can currently represent a value of up to 31 bits along with a one-bit sign (positive or negative). This set-defined primitive type cannot be represented as blank.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • UINT_4

        public static final int UINT_4
        An unsigned, four-byte integer type. Can currently represent an unsigned value with precision of up to 32 bits. This set-defined primitive type cannot be represented as blank.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • INT_8

        public static final int INT_8
        A signed, eight-byte integer type. Can currently represent a value of up to 63 bits along with a one-bit sign (positive or negative). This set-defined primitive type cannot be represented as blank.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • UINT_8

        public static final int UINT_8
        An unsigned, eight-byte integer type. Can currently represent an unsigned value with precision of up to 64 bits. This set-defined primitive type cannot be represented as blank.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • FLOAT_4

        public static final int FLOAT_4
        A four-byte, floating point type. Can represent the same range of values allowed with the system float type. Follows the IEEE 754 specification. This set-defined primitive type cannot be represented as blank.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • DOUBLE_8

        public static final int DOUBLE_8
        An eight-byte, floating point type. Can represent the same range of values allowed with the system double type. Follows the IEEE 754 specification. This set-defined primitive type cannot be represented as blank.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • REAL_4RB

        public static final int REAL_4RB
        An optimized RWF representation of a decimal or fractional value which typically requires less bytes on the wire than float or double types. This type allows for up to a four-byte value with a hint for converting to decimal or fractional representation. This set-defined primitive type can be represented as blank.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • REAL_8RB

        public static final int REAL_8RB
        An optimized RWF representation of a decimal or fractional value which typically requires less bytes on the wire than float or double types. This type allows for up to eight bytes of value with a hint for converting to decimal or fractional representation. This set-defined primitive type can be represented as blank.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

        public static final int DATE_4
        4-byte representation of a date containing month, day, and year values. This value can be represented as blank
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

        public static final int TIME_3
        3 byte representation of a time containing hour, minute, and second values. This value can be represented as blank
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • TIME_5

        public static final int TIME_5
        5 byte Representation of a time containing hour, minute, second, and millisecond values. This value can be represented as blank.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • DATETIME_7

        public static final int DATETIME_7
        7 byte combined representation of date and time. Contains all members of Date and hour, minute, and second from Time. This value can be represented as blank.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • DATETIME_9

        public static final int DATETIME_9
        9 byte combined representation of date and time. Contains all members of Date and hour, minute, second, and millisecond from Time. This value can be represented as blank.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • DATETIME_11

        public static final int DATETIME_11
        11 byte combined representation of date and time. Contains all members of Date and hour, minute, second, millisecond, and microsecond from Time. This value can be represented as blank.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • DATETIME_12

        public static final int DATETIME_12
        12 byte combined representation of date and time. Contains all members of Date and hour, minute, second, millisecond, microsecond, and nanosecond from Time. This value can be represented as blank.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

        public static final int TIME_7
        7 byte Representation of a time containing hour, minute, second, millisecond, and microsecond values. This value can be represented as blank.
        See Also:

      • XML

        public static final int XML
        XML formatted data, use Non-RWF type encoders
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • FIELD_LIST

        public static final int FIELD_LIST
        A highly optimized, non-uniform type, that contains field identifier-value paired entries. fieldId refers to specific name and type information as defined in an external field dictionary (such as RDMFieldDictionary).

        Entry Information: Entry type is FieldEntry, which can house any DataTypes, including set-defined data, base primitive types, and container types.

        • If the information and entry being updated contains a primitive type, any previously stored or displayed data is replaced.
        • If the entry contains another container type, action values associated with that type specify how to update the information.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • ELEMENT_LIST

        public static final int ELEMENT_LIST
        A self-describing, non-uniform type, with each entry containing name, dataType, and a value. This type is equivalent to FieldList, but without the optimizations provided through fieldId use.

        Entry Information: Entry type is ElementEntry, which can house any DataTypes, including set-defined data, base primitive types, and container types.

        • If the updating information and entry contain a primitive type, any previously stored or displayed data is replaced.
        • If the entry contains another container type, action values associated with that type specify how to update the information.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • ANSI_PAGE

        public static final int ANSI_PAGE
        Indicates that contents are ANSI Page format, use Non-RWF type encoders
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • FILTER_LIST

        public static final int FILTER_LIST
        A non-uniform container of filterId-value paired entries. A filterId corresponds to one of 32 possible bit-value identifiers, typically defined by a domain model specification. FilterId's can be used to indicate interest or presence of specific entries through the inclusion of the filterId in the message key's filter member.

        Entry Information: Entry type is FilterEntry, which can house only container types. Though the FilterList can specify a containerType, each entry can override this specification to house a different type. Each entry has an associated action, which informs the user of how to apply the information stored in the entry.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • VECTOR

        public static final int VECTOR
        A container of position index-value paired entries. This container is a uniform type, where the containerType of each entry's payload is specified on the Vector. Each entry's index is represented by an unsigned integer.

        Entry Information: Entry type is VectorEntry, which can house only container types, as specified on the Vector. Each entry's index is an unsigned integer. Each entry has an associated action, which informs the user of how to apply the information stored in the entry.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • MAP

        public static final int MAP
        A container of key-value paired entries. Map is a uniform type, where the base primitive type of each entry's key and the containerType of each entry's payload are specified on the Map.

        Entry Information: Entry type is MapEntry, which can include only container types, as specified on the Map. Each entry's key is a base primitive type, as specified on the Map. Each entry has an associated action, which informs the user of how to apply the information stored in the entry.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • SERIES

        public static final int SERIES
        A uniform type, where the containerType of each entry is specified on the Series. This container is often used to represent table-based information, where no explicit indexing is present or required. As entries are received, the user should append them to any previously-received entries.

        Entry Information: Entry type is SeriesEntry, which can include only container types, as specified on the Series. SeriesEntry types do not contain explicit actions; though as entries are received, the user should append them to any previously received entries.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • MSG

        public static final int MSG
        Indicates that the contents are another message. This allows the application to house a message within a message or a message within another container's entries. This type is typically used with posting.

        Entry Information: None

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • JSON

        public static final int JSON
        Indicates that the contents are JSON encoded. Use Non-RWF encoders and decoders to process content, likely a JSON encoding/decoding library.

        Entry Information: None

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • CONTAINER_TYPE_MAX

        public static final int CONTAINER_TYPE_MAX
        Maximum supported container type value for this release.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

    • Method Detail

      • toString

        public static java.lang.String toString(int dataType)
        Provides string representation for a data type value.
        Parameters:
        dataType - DataTypes enumeration to convert to string
        Returns:
        string representation for a data type value

      • isPrimitiveType

        public static boolean isPrimitiveType(int dataType)
        Checks if the passed in type is a valid primitive type.
        Parameters:
        dataType - DataTypes enumerated value to check
        Returns:
        true if passed in type is a valid primitive type or false if not

      • isContainerType

        public static boolean isContainerType(int dataType)
        Checks if the passed in type is a valid container type.
        Parameters:
        dataType - DataTypes enumerated value to check
        Returns:
        true if passed in type is a valid container type or false if not

      • primitiveTypeSize

        public static int primitiveTypeSize(int dataType)
        Returns maximum encoded size for primitiveTypes.
        Parameters:
        dataType - DataTypes enumerated value to return encoded size for
        Returns:
        maximum encoded size when this can be determined, 255 (0xFF) for types that contain buffer content whose length varies based on Buffer.length(), or 0 for invalid types
